**1.Please describe what your data looks like and where you got it. Identify what the variables and samples are. Describe how the data was originally created.**

The dataset consists of information about current employees, their salaries, and position titles within various departments of an organization.

#### *Variables*
  1. Job Titles: The title of the job held by the employee.
  2. Department: The department where the employee works.
  3. Full or Part-Time: Indicates whether the employee works full time (F) or part time (P).
  4. Salary or Hourly: Specifies if the employee is paid a salary or on an hourly basis.
  5. Typical Hours: The typical number of hours worked per week by hourly employees (non-null only for hourly workers).
  6. Annual Salary: The annual salary for salaried employees (non-null only for salaried workers).
  7. Hourly Rate: The hourly rate for hourly employees (non-null only for hourly workers).
  
#### *Data Description*
- The data set consists of 31,887 entries.
- There are non-null entries for all employees in the categories of job titles, department, full or part-time status, and salary or hourly status.
- Typical hours, annual salary, and hourly rate are populated based on whether an employee is hourly or salaried. For example, hourly employees have entries under "Typical Hours" and "Hourly Rate," whereas salaried employees have entries under "Annual Salary."
  
#### *Data Origin*
This data seems to be an official record from a public or large private organization, possibly tabeled for administrative, financial planning, or human resource management purposes. It reflects structured employment data that would typically be maintained in a payroll or human resources information system.
This data is valuable for analysis related to employment patterns, salary distributions, and departmental staffing within the organization.

**2.Perform at least three different data sub-setting, cleaning, or manipulation methods that were described in this course on your data. Examples are: renaming the columns, recording values, reshaping the data, filtering the data, etc.**
```{r}
project <- read.csv("Project.csv")
project <- rename(project,Name_of_the_Job = Job.Titles)
project <- rownames_to_column(project,"Serial number")
head(project, n=5)
# I have created a column where total annual hourly salary is calculated by making an assumption individual will be working 50 weeks in an year
project$HourlySalary <- 50* project$Typical.Hours * project$Hourly.Rate
project$TotalSalary <- ifelse(is.na(project$Annual.Salary), project$HourlySalary, project$Annual.Salary)
head(project, n=10)
```

**5.Perform a numeric summarization of your data motivated by patterns observed in Step 4. This can involve summarizing the data to describe aspects about it (quartiles, means, range etc.).**

```{r}
summary_project <- summary(project$TotalSalary)
print(summary_project)
sd_project <- sd(project$TotalSalary) 
range_project <- range(project$TotalSalary)


cat("Summary of TotalSalary:\n", summary_project, "\nStandard Deviation of TotalSalary:", sd_project, 
    "\nRange of TotalSalary:", range_project, sep="\n")
mean_Totalsalary <- mean(project$TotalSalary,na.rm = TRUE)
mean_Totalsalary
median_Totalsalary <- median(project$TotalSalary)
median_Totalsalary
range_Totalsalary <- range(project$TotalSalary)
range_Totalsalary
```
